p: By limiting primary viral infection, influenza vaccination has the ability to decrease secondary bacterial infections [83]. Similarly, prevention and treatment of secondary bacterial infections may help decrease the burden of influenza. Notably, a prospective study conducted in Sweden showed that influenza and pneumococcal vaccinations in individuals aged ≥ 65 years substantially reduced influenza- and pneumonia-related hospitalizations, and reduced mortality from all causes by 57% in this age group [87].
